posts.cooked: I want to implement a “dynamic” standard deviation values for our vision measurements (i.e. the stdDevs will increase the further the robot is from the april tags), we are using LimeLightHelpers (megatag2) to get the pose estimates. Should it be “linear” by multiplying the average distance by some value or is there a better solution?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Take some data and find out!  This is actually a pretty complicated problem, and you can help set the best practice by doing some research.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: That makes sense. Do you have any advice or approaches you would recommend me for how to go about researching that? As i don’t really have an idea on how to “evaluate” the standard deviation of a measurement to know if its correct or it isn’t.

Localization: Finding Standard Deviations for SetVisionMeasurementStdDevs Java

Here’s another response to a very similar question!

link_counts.title: Localization: Finding Standard Deviations for SetVisionMeasurementStdDevs

posts.cooked:
Outside of calculating it, tuning standard deviations CAN BE superficially similar to tuning PID . Make small changes and see how well it works.

What this would look like is messing around with your standard deviations for a variety of distances, and once you find a good-looking deviation for each, then put it into an Excel/Calc spreadsheet. From there you can create a linear/quadratic regression based on this data, and plug it into your code to get a dynamic standard deviation.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I’d start by measuring some standard deviations of your vision inputs at different distances.  Look up “moving window standard deviation” for some algorithms!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: Thank you all for the help, i will be testing out the solutions you provided

I’ve been doing some thinking, and I’ll be using NumPy to calculate standard deviations since I’m already familiar with it.

My plan is to create three “models”, each based on how many AprilTags are detected:

One model for 1 tag

One for 2 tags

One for 3 or more tags (since seeing more than 3 at once is unlikely)

Each model will be a linear function with multiple variables that I think affect the standard deviation.

For 1 tag: the only variable will be the distance to the tag.

For 2+ tags: the variables will be average tag distance and tag span (both available from Limelight’s pose estimate).

To collect data, the robot will be stationary at a known distance and will continuously send pose estimates to NetworkTables. I’ll run a Python script on my laptop to receive the data and calculate standard deviations using NumPy.

Once I have enough datasets, I’ll fit a linear function using:

I’m aware there are other possible factors (like avgTagArea ), so I’ll save them too. I won’t use them initially, but I’ll have the data if I want to expand the model later.

I would appreciate any thoughts or feedback before I start going forward with that plan.

TheBatman:

np.linalg.lstsq

Have you considered using an Interpolating Double Tree Map ? That will probably match the data you collect empirically better than fitting a straight line.

Does this support having multiple arguments? From what i see in the link you provided it gets a double and returns a double - so it will be nice if i only use Distance - but i plan to also use other arguments.

If not- I have heard that there is an option of fitting a polynomial function with multiple arguments using NumPy - just Im not sure what should be the degree of the polynomial function.
Actually after researching about interpolating you inspired me to maybe try to implement my own 2d and 3d interpolating double tree maps, So i will try to implement it and see how it goes.
